title: Manipulate report timeline activity by using null byte.

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Null bytes are not permitted in report body, or even in report title. But that can be used in the comment section of `self-closing` (for reporter) and `change-status` (for team). When a null byte is used as a comment, that report timeline activity disappears!

For example: 
https://hackerone.com/reports/133317 report was closed using a null byte in comment.

{F88258}

There is no activity log in the report details for the closing, but the report is closed.
vulnerability_information_html:
Null bytes are not permitted in report body, or even in report title. But that can be used in the comment section of self-closing (for reporter) and change-status (for team). When a null byte is used as a comment, that report timeline activity disappears!

For example:
https://hackerone.com/reports/133317 report was closed using a null byte in comment.

There is no activity log in the report details for the closing, but the report is closed.

activities.message:
From the **JSON** response of https://hackerone.com/reports/133317.json
```json
"bug_reporter_agreed_on_going_public_at": "2016-04-20T20:11:43.986Z",
```
During public disclosure request, I have used null byte as well. Thats why that activity is also hidden. What if this is an actual report and the reporter requests public disclosure by using null byte. Team member will not see that public disclosure activity and he will not be able to take action.
activities.markdown_message:
From the JSON response of https://hackerone.com/reports/133317.json

"bug_reporter_agreed_on_going_public_at": "2016-04-20T20:11:43.986Z",

During public disclosure request, I have used null byte as well. Thats why that activity is also hidden. What if this is an actual report and the reporter requests public disclosure by using null byte. Team member will not see that public disclosure activity and he will not be able to take action.

activities.message:
I am not sure about the policy of disclosing n/a report. If mutual agreement is required for n/a disclosing, then its alright. But if that 30 days limit exist on n/a disclosure, a big problem will raise, I guess.
1. Reporter reports a bug.
2. Reporter Self-closes the bug.
3. Reporter requests disclosure with null byte.
4. No activity on bug report about disclosing.
5. Report discloses after 30 days.
activities.markdown_message:
I am not sure about the policy of disclosing n/a report. If mutual agreement is required for n/a disclosing, then its alright. But if that 30 days limit exist on n/a disclosure, a big problem will raise, I guess.

  1. Reporter reports a bug.
  2. Reporter Self-closes the bug.
  3. Reporter requests disclosure with null byte.
  4. No activity on bug report about disclosing.
  5. Report discloses after 30 days.

activities.message:
Hey @siddiki,

Thanks for the report! Thankfully, the 30 day limit doesn't exist on N/A reports requested by the reporter doesn't exist, so I think the impact of this is limited to a hacker being able to hide his own comments. That said, it's definitely something that's interesting and should be fixed long-term, so I'm going to close it as informative.

Thanks! And Happy Hacking!


Evan
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @siddiki,

Thanks for the report! Thankfully, the 30 day limit doesn't exist on N/A reports requested by the reporter doesn't exist, so I think the impact of this is limited to a hacker being able to hide his own comments. That said, it's definitely something that's interesting and should be fixed long-term, so I'm going to close it as informative.

Thanks! And Happy Hacking!

Evan

activities.message:
@ebrynne , giving you some more ground regarding null byte issue.

**Team Member**
1. Team member can also use null byte to hide their comment on activity.
2. Team member can close bug using null byte and no one will ever know who did that.
3. Team member can assign bug to someone else, no one will ever know who did that.
4. Team member can also request disclosure without revealing his identity.
5. If team member invites ```user[nullbyte]@domain.com```, parts after null will be truncated and https://hackerone.com/user will receive the invitation instead.

I hope, there is enough reason to reconsider the case now.
activities.markdown_message:
@ebrynne , giving you some more ground regarding null byte issue.

Team Member

  1. Team member can also use null byte to hide their comment on activity.
  2. Team member can close bug using null byte and no one will ever know who did that.
  3. Team member can assign bug to someone else, no one will ever know who did that.
  4. Team member can also request disclosure without revealing his identity.
  5. If team member invites user[nullbyte]@domain.com, parts after null will be truncated and https://hackerone.com/user will receive the invitation instead.

I hope, there is enough reason to reconsider the case now.

activities.message:
Hackerone does not accept a blank report. There is a check implemented to detect null bytes in report title and body. But we can use unmapped Unicode character (boxes with numbers/ hex code)  in reports. That will make the report title and body visually empty.

**example** 
https://hackerone.com/reports/133880 is a report which contains empty title and body and closed with null bytes.
activities.markdown_message:
Hackerone does not accept a blank report. There is a check implemented to detect null bytes in report title and body. But we can use unmapped Unicode character (boxes with numbers/ hex code) in reports. That will make the report title and body visually empty.

example
https://hackerone.com/reports/133880 is a report which contains empty title and body and closed with null bytes.

activities.message:
Hey @siddiki,

Although all of the cases you list could definitely be annoying, I don't believe any of them are exploitable security concerns. Even the most concerning case (team members hiding their activities) requires significant additional social engineering from an existing team member to transform into something dangerous (I'm not even certain what they could do with that capability). As such, I stand by my original decision. 

Thank you for your understanding!


Evan
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message: ​Please accept the disclosure request. I am comfortable with your decision ​but want to share it with the people out there.
activities.markdown_message: ​Please accept the disclosure request. I am comfortable with your decision ​but want to share it with the people out there.

activities.message: This is indeed a valid issue which should be treated accordingly. I understand the reported issue does not warrant an urgent fix, but definitely, the issue deserves to be remediated. I believe the part of the issue regarding team activity (point 3 and 4 of activity-921783) have enough reason to be reconsidered. If you disagree, I have full respect for your decision, but please response at least.

If you disagree, I have full respect for your decision, but please response at least.

Just to keep you posted, the team is still discussing internally if we want to disclose the report or not. We will update you soon. Thanks for the patience.

Thanks !

activities.message:
I asked multiple time to come to a decision. I strongly believe that the vulnerability should be accepted and disclosed. HackerOne team didn't bother to respond back. That's why asking Hackerone to mediate the issue of a HackerOne report. 
Funny!

activities.message: Sorry for the long wait on this one @siddiki!
activities.markdown_message: Sorry for the long wait on this one @siddiki!

summaries.content: @siddiki reported to us that under certain conditions it is possible to make select actions on a report happen but not appear in the report timeline. We reviewed the potential security consequences as a result of this behavior and came to the conclusion this is a low priority functionality bug with no unacceptable security risks.
summaries.content_html: @siddiki reported to us that under certain conditions it is possible to make select actions on a report happen but not appear in the report timeline. We reviewed the potential security consequences as a result of this behavior and came to the conclusion this is a low priority functionality bug with no unacceptable security risks.
